title: How to Substitute Cooking Alcohols

methods.name: Replacing Hard Liquors Used in Cooking

steps.headline: Exchange bourbon for vanilla extract.
steps.description: Bourbon is a sweet kind of whiskey produced in America. To duplicate the sweet flavor imparted by bourbon, use 1 to 2 tsp (7.4 to 10 ml) of vanilla extract for every 2 tablespoons of bourbon. Mix it into your recipe in the same fashion described for adding the bourbon. For recipes that call for less bourbon or that are suited to lighter intensity sweetness, use less vanilla extract. Recipes suited to strong intensity sweetness will benefit from more extract. Bourbon chicken is a recipe where you easily substitute vanilla for bourbon.

steps.headline: Substitute brandy for brandy or rum flavoring, or use fruit juice.
steps.description: For every 2 tsp (10 ml) of brandy needed in a recipe, use ½ to 1 tsp (2.5 to 5 ml) of brandy or rum extract. If larger amounts of brandy are required, use water or fruit juice in the same amount. Brandy frequently has a fruit flavor, like plum or apple. When subbing fruit juice, choose one that has a similar taste to the flavor of brandy called for in the recipe.

steps.headline: Replace rum with fruit juices.
steps.description: Fruit juices, like grape juice, pineapple juice, and apple juice work well as rum alternatives. Use the same amount of fruit juice as you would rum. You can also round out the flavor profile of your fruit juice by adding ½ to 1 tsp (2.5 to 5 ml) of nonalcoholic rum, vanilla extract, or almond extract to the juice.

steps.headline: Swap vodka for fruit juices or water.
steps.description: Vodka in recipes can be replaced with an equal amount of water. However, to achieve the flavor profile imparted by vodka more closely, mix white grape juice or apple cider with a few drops of lime juice. When using grape or apple cider for vodka, the amount of juice should be the same as the amount called for in the recipe.

steps.headline: Use cactus juice or nectar for tequila.
steps.description: Tequila is made from a desert plant called agave, and by using juice or nectar from other desert plants, especially cactus, you can recreate the taste of tequila in your cooking. Generally, you should use an equivalent amount of cactus juice or nectar for the tequila.

steps.headline: Eliminate whiskey altogether in recipes that call for a splash.
steps.description: Many recipes only call for a small amount of whiskey. In some recipes, you may see this described as adding a “splash” of whiskey. In many of these situations, you can remove the whiskey from the recipe completely to little effect.

methods.name: Swapping Cooking Wines and Beers for Other Ingredients

steps.headline: Sub broths for beer or ale in recipes.
steps.description: Regular kinds of beer or ale can be replaced with an equal amount of strong broth, like chicken, beef, or mushroom broth. Light beers will only need a normal chicken broth, but you can also use white grape juice or ginger ale. When adding normal chicken broth, white grape juice, or ginger ale, use as much of the substitute as alcoholic beer. Nonalcoholic beer can also be used as a substitute for beer in recipes that call for this ingredient. Try subbing broth for beer when making beer bratwursts.

steps.headline: Simulate Gewürztraminer with white grape and lemon juice.
steps.description: Gewurztraminer is a spicy wine made from white grapes. This makes white grape juice an ideal alternative. Replicate the taste even more closely by adding a few drops of lemon juice to the substitute.

steps.headline: Use nonalcoholic wines with vinegar in place of red and white wine.
steps.description:
Red and white wine both can be substituted with an equal amount of nonalcoholic wine with 1 tbsp (14.8 ml) of white wine vinegar. You could also replace the wine in recipes with an equal amount of:
Grape juice (red for red wine, white for white wine)
Cranberry juice (red wine)
Apple juice (white wine)
Water (both for red and white)

steps.headline: Replace carbonated wines with soda or sparkling juices.
steps.description: Many recipes call for carbonated wines, like champagne or sparkling wine. In place of these, use an equal amount of ginger ale, sparkling apple cider, sparkling cranberry juice, or even sparkling white grape juice.

steps.headline: Change rice wine (sake) to rice vinegar in recipes.
steps.description: Japanese rice wine, called sake, is made from fermented rice. As rice vinegar is also made by fermenting rice, this makes it an excellent replacement. Use an equal amount of rice vinegar as rice wine.

steps.headline: Alter recipes that call for port by using juices and citrus fruit.
steps.description: Port is a kind of fortified wine. You can imitate regular ports in recipes with an equal amount of concord grape juice with a little lime zest added in. Some recipes may call for a light port. In this case, use orange juice or apple juice in the same amount as the port.

steps.headline: Replace amaretto with almond extract or Italian soda syrup.
steps.description: Amaretto is a liqueur made from almonds. However, because the flavor of almond extract is so concentrated, when subbing it for amaretto you should only use ½ tsp (2.5 ml) for every 2 tbsp (30 ml) of amaretto. If you don’t have almond extract, you can also use an equal amount of Italian soda syrup in place of the amaretto. This syrup can usually be bought at your local grocery store. Use almond extract in place of amaretto to impart a nutty flavor to a tiramisu.

steps.headline: Use raspberry juice, syrup, or extract for Chambord liqueur.
steps.description: Chambord is a liqueur with a potent raspberry flavor. Replace it in your recipes with an equal amount of raspberry juice, syrup, or extract. In some cases, you may want to halve the amount of extract you use, as its flavor may be too strong otherwise.

steps.headline: Substitute coffee liqueur with chocolate extract and instant coffee.
steps.description:
For every 2 tbsp (30 ml) of coffee flavored liqueur, like Tia Maria or Kahlua, substitute ½ to 1 tsp (2.5 to 5 ml) of chocolate extract and 1 tsp (5 ml) of instant coffee mixed with 2 tbsp (30 ml) of water. Other substitutes include equal amounts of:
Espresso
Nonalcoholic coffee extract
Coffee syrup

steps.headline: Imitate orange liqueurs in recipes with orange juice and extract.
steps.description: Orange flavored liqueurs, like Cointreau and Grand Marnier, are common in recipes. For every 2 tbsp (30 ml) of these liqueurs, use 2 tbsp (30 ml) of orange juice concentrate mixed with ½ tsp (2.5 ml) of orange extract. If you don’t have orange juice concentrate, feel free to use 2 tbsp (30 ml) of regular orange juice with ½ tsp of orange extract.

steps.headline: Replace Frangelico with hazelnut or almond extract.
steps.description: Frangelico has a rich hazelnut flavor that can be difficult to replace. However, when a recipe calls for Frangelico or a hazelnut liqueur, you can replicate the flavor by using an equal amount of hazelnut or almond extract.

steps.headline: Swap licorice liqueurs with licorice flavorings.
steps.description: Liqueurs with a licorice flavor, like Sambuca and Galliano, can often be swapped out for licorice extract. However, you can also use an equal amount of anise flavored Italian soda syrup or fennel.

text:
Replacing Hard Liquors Used in Cooking Exchange bourbon for vanilla extract. Bourbon is a sweet kind of whiskey produced in America. To duplicate the sweet flavor imparted by bourbon, use 1 to 2 tsp (7.4 to 10 ml) of vanilla extract for every 2 tablespoons of bourbon. Mix it into your recipe in the same fashion described for adding the bourbon. For recipes that call for less bourbon or that are suited to lighter intensity sweetness, use less vanilla extract. Recipes suited to strong intensity sweetness will benefit from more extract. Bourbon chicken is a recipe where you easily substitute vanilla for bourbon. Substitute brandy for brandy or rum flavoring, or use fruit juice. For every 2 tsp (10 ml) of brandy needed in a recipe, use ½ to 1 tsp (2.5 to 5 ml) of brandy or rum extract. If larger amounts of brandy are required, use water or fruit juice in the same amount. Brandy frequently has a fruit flavor, like plum or apple. When subbing fruit juice, choose one that has a similar taste to the flavor of brandy called for in the recipe. Replace rum with fruit juices. Fruit juices, like grape juice, pineapple juice, and apple juice work well as rum alternatives. Use the same amount of fruit juice as you would rum. You can also round out the flavor profile of your fruit juice by adding ½ to 1 tsp (2.5 to 5 ml) of nonalcoholic rum, vanilla extract, or almond extract to the juice. Swap vodka for fruit juices or water. Vodka in recipes can be replaced with an equal amount of water. However, to achieve the flavor profile imparted by vodka more closely, mix white grape juice or apple cider with a few drops of lime juice. When using grape or apple cider for vodka, the amount of juice should be the same as the amount called for in the recipe. Use cactus juice or nectar for tequila. Tequila is made from a desert plant called agave, and by using juice or nectar from other desert plants, especially cactus, you can recreate the taste of tequila in your cooking. Generally, you should use an equivalent amount of cactus juice or nectar for the tequila. Eliminate whiskey altogether in recipes that call for a splash. Many recipes only call for a small amount of whiskey. In some recipes, you may see this described as adding a “splash” of whiskey. In many of these situations, you can remove the whiskey from the recipe completely to little effect. Swapping Cooking Wines and Beers for Other Ingredients Sub broths for beer or ale in recipes. Regular kinds of beer or ale can be replaced with an equal amount of strong broth, like chicken, beef, or mushroom broth. When adding normal chicken broth, white grape juice, or ginger ale, use as much of the substitute as alcoholic beer. Simulate Gewürztraminer with white grape and lemon juice. Gewurztraminer is a spicy wine made from white grapes. This makes white grape juice an ideal alternative. Replicate the taste even more closely by adding a few drops of lemon juice to the substitute. Use nonalcoholic wines with vinegar in place of red and white wine. Grape juice (red for red wine, white for white wine)

Water (both for red and white) Replace carbonated wines with soda or sparkling juices. Many recipes call for carbonated wines, like champagne or sparkling wine. In place of these, use an equal amount of ginger ale, sparkling apple cider, sparkling cranberry juice, or even sparkling white grape juice. Change rice wine (sake) to rice vinegar in recipes. Japanese rice wine, called sake, is made from fermented rice. As rice vinegar is also made by fermenting rice, this makes it an excellent replacement. Use an equal amount of rice vinegar as rice wine. Alter recipes that call for port by using juices and citrus fruit. Port is a kind of fortified wine. You can imitate regular ports in recipes with an equal amount of concord grape juice with a little lime zest added in. Some recipes may call for a light port. In this case, use orange juice or apple juice in the same amount as the port. Substituting for Liqueurs in Recipes Replace amaretto with almond extract or Italian soda syrup. Amaretto is a liqueur made from almonds. However, because the flavor of almond extract is so concentrated, when subbing it for amaretto you should only use ½ tsp (2.5 ml) for every 2 tbsp (30 ml) of amaretto. If you don’t have almond extract, you can also use an equal amount of Italian soda syrup in place of the amaretto. This syrup can usually be bought at your local grocery store. Use almond extract in place of amaretto to impart a nutty flavor to a tiramisu. Use raspberry juice, syrup, or extract for Chambord liqueur. Chambord is a liqueur with a potent raspberry flavor. Replace it in your recipes with an equal amount of raspberry juice, syrup, or extract. In some cases, you may want to halve the amount of extract you use, as its flavor may be too strong otherwise. Substitute coffee liqueur with chocolate extract and instant coffee. For every 2 tbsp (30 ml) of coffee flavored liqueur, like Tia Maria or Kahlua, substitute ½ to 1 tsp (2.5 to 5 ml) of chocolate extract and 1 tsp (5 ml) of instant coffee mixed with 2 tbsp (30 ml) of water. Other substitutes include equal amounts of:
Espresso
Nonalcoholic coffee extract
Coffee syrup Imitate orange liqueurs in recipes with orange juice and extract. Orange flavored liqueurs, like Cointreau and Grand Marnier, are common in recipes. For every 2 tbsp (30 ml) of these liqueurs, use 2 tbsp (30 ml) of orange juice concentrate mixed with ½ tsp (2.5 ml) of orange extract. If you don’t have orange juice concentrate, feel free to use 2 tbsp (30 ml) of regular orange juice with ½ tsp of orange extract. Replace Frangelico with hazelnut or almond extract. Frangelico has a rich hazelnut flavor that can be difficult to replace. However, when a recipe calls for Frangelico or a hazelnut liqueur, you can replicate the flavor by using an equal amount of hazelnut or almond extract. Swap licorice liqueurs with licorice flavorings. Liqueurs with a licorice flavor, like Sambuca and Galliano, can often be swapped out for licorice extract. However, you can also use an equal amount of anise flavored Italian soda syrup or fennel.
